text: Hop into Rust's science and AI chatroom and see love for JuliaLang. What a nice thing :)

elements.text: Hop into Rust's science and AI chatroom and see love for JuliaLang. What a nice thing :)

text: I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected

elements.text: I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected

text: Yea I think the idea is, Julia is amazing for mathy stuff, Rust is pretty awesome for systemsy stuff. If you need mathy systemsy stuff, it makes sense to use both :slightly_smiling_face:. But I agree very different end use for the tools.

elements.text: Yea I think the idea is, Julia is amazing for mathy stuff, Rust is pretty awesome for systemsy stuff. If you need mathy systemsy stuff, it makes sense to use both
. But I agree very different end use for the tools.

text:
> I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected
presumably this is exactly why they have good things to say about Julia. Overlapping domains leads to combative attitudes

elements.text: I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected
presumably this is exactly why they have good things to say about Julia. Overlapping domains leads to combative attitudes

text: Presumably, these users wouldn’t see a success for Julia as a loss for Rust.

elements.text: Presumably, these users wouldn’t see a success for Julia as a loss for Rust.

text: One of the things that I think would massively help both languages is if we could get more people bringing knowledge back and forth. Some sort of convention for open source language writing would be great. I'm sure there are a ton of really cool techniques that could be broadly applicable, but are currently siloed knowledge to 1 comunity

elements.text: One of the things that I think would massively help both languages is if we could get more people bringing knowledge back and forth. Some sort of convention for open source language writing would be great. I'm sure there are a ton of really cool techniques that could be broadly applicable, but are currently siloed knowledge to 1 comunity

text: I’ve been interested in Rust (and now Zig) for making low-level libraries (where there is no need for being able to use different types) that can be easily used via ccall from Julia.   It’s a step up from using C libraries :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I’ve been interested in Rust (and now Zig) for making low-level libraries (where there is no need for being able to use different types) that can be easily used via ccall from Julia.   It’s a step up from using C libraries
